sentences.sentence: Can you imagine a stretch( 一片 ) of grassy land bubbling( 冒泡 ) like water in a pot?
For that is really the best description of what was happening.
In all directions it was swelling( 膨胀 ) into humps( 土丘 ).
They were of very different sizes, some no bigger than mole-hills( 鼹鼠丘 ), some as big as wheelbarrows( 独轮车 ), two the size of cottages.
And the humps( 土丘 ) moved and swelled( 膨胀 ) till they burst, and the crumbled( 粉碎的 ) earth poured out of them, and from each hump( 土丘 ) there came out an animal.
The moles( 鼹鼠 ) came out just as you might see a mole( 鼹鼠 ) come out in England.
The dogs came out, barking the moment their heads were free, and struggling as you’ve seen them do when they are getting through a narrow hole in a hedge( 树篱 ).
The stags( 牡鹿 ) were the queerest( 最奇怪的 ) to watch, for of course the antlers( 鹿角 ) came up a long time before the rest of them, so at first Digory thought they were trees.
The frogs, who all came up near the river, went straight into it with a plop( 扑通声 )-plop( 扑通声 ) and a loud croaking( 蛙鸣声 ).

The panthers( 黑豹 ), leopards( 美洲豹 ) and things of that sort, sat down at once to wash the loose( 松的 ) earth off their hind quarters and then stood up against the trees to sharpen( 磨 ) their front claws.
Showers of birds came out of the trees. Butterflies fluttered( 拍打翅膀 ).
Bees got to work on the flowers as if they hadn’t a second to lose.

But the greatest moment of all was when the biggest hump( 土丘 ) broke like a small earthquake and out came the sloping( 倾斜的 ) back, the large, wise head, and the four baggy( 肥大的 )-trousered legs of an elephant.

And now you could hardly hear the song of the Lion; there was so much cawing( 鸦叫 ), cooing( （鸽子等）咕咕叫 ), crowing( （公鸡）啼叫 ), braying( （驴）嘶叫 ), neighing( （马）嘶鸣 ), baying( （狼）嚎叫 ), barking, lowing( （牛）哞哞叫 ), bleating( （羊）咩咩叫 ), and trumpeting( （大象）吼叫 ).
But though Digory could no longer hear the Lion, he could see it.
It was so big and so bright that he could not take his eyes off it.
The other animals did not appear to be afraid of it. Indeed, at that very moment, Digory heard the sound of hoofs( 马蹄 ) from behind;
a second later the old cab( 出租马车 )-horse trotted( 小跑 ) past him and joined the other beasts.
(The air had apparently suited him as well as it had suited Uncle Andrew.
He no longer looked like the poor, old slave he had been in London; he was picking up his feet and holding his head erect( 竖直的 ).)
And now, for the first time, the Lion was quite silent.
He was going to and fro( 来回地 ) among the animals.
And every now and then he would go up to two of them (always two at a time) and touch their noses with his.
He would touch two beavers( 海狸 ) among all the beavers( 海狸 ), two leopards( 美洲豹 ) among all the leopards( 美洲豹 ), one stag( 牡鹿 ) and one deer among all the deer, and leave the rest.
Some sorts of animal he passed over( 忽略 ) altogether.
But the pairs which he had touched instantly left their own kinds and followed him.
At last he stood still and all the creatures whom he had touched came and stood in a wide circle around him.
The others whom he had not touched began to wander away( 离开 ).
Their noises faded( 渐渐消失 ) gradually into the distance.
The chosen beasts who remained were now utterly( 完全地 ) silent, all with their eyes fixed intently upon the Lion.
The cat-like ones gave an occasional twitch( 抖动 ) of the tail but otherwise all were still.
For the first time that day there was complete silence, except for the noise of running water. Digory’s heart beat wildly;
he knew something very solemn( 庄严的 ) was going to be done.
He had not forgotten about his Mother; but he knew jolly well( 无疑 ) that, even for her, he couldn’t interrupt a thing like this.
The Lion, whose eyes never blinked( 眨眼 ), stared at the animals as hard as if he was going to burn them up with his mere stare.
And gradually a change came over them.
The smaller ones—the rabbits, moles( 鼹鼠 ) and such-like—grew a good deal larger.
The very big ones—you noticed it most with the elephants—grew a little smaller.
Many animals sat up on their hind legs( 后腿 ).
Most put their heads on one side as if they were trying very hard to understand.
The Lion opened his mouth, but no sound came from it; he was breathing out, a long, warm breath;
it seemed to sway( 使摇摆 ) all the beasts as the wind sways( 使摇摆 ) a line of trees.
Far overhead( 在头顶上方 ) from beyond the veil( 幕布 ) of blue sky which hid them the stars sang again; a pure, cold, difficult music.
There came a swift( 迅速的 ) flash like fire (but it burnt nobody) either from the sky or from the Lion itself,
and every drop of blood tingled( 感到兴奋 ) in the children’s bodies,
and the deepest, wildest voice they had ever heard was saying:
“Narnia, Narnia, Narnia, awake. Love. Think. Speak. Be walking trees. Be talking beasts. Be divine( 神圣的 ) waters.”
It was of course the Lion’s voice.
The children had long felt sure that he could speak: yet it was a lovely and terrible shock when he did.
Out of the trees wild people stepped forth( 向外 ), gods and goddesses of the wood; with them came Fauns and Satyrs and Dwarfs.
Out of the river rose the river god with his Naiad( 水泽仙女 ) daughters.
And all these and all the beasts and birds in their different voices, low or high or thick or clear, replied:
“Hail( 万岁 ), Aslan. We hear and obey. We are awake. We love. We think. We speak. We know.”
“But please, we don’t know very much yet,” said a nosey and snorty( 带鼻音的 ) kind of voice.
And that really did make the children jump, for it was the cab( 出租马车 )-horse who had spoken.
“Good old Strawberry,” said Polly. “I am glad he was one of the ones picked out to be a Talking Beast.”
And the Cabby( 马车夫 ), who was now standing beside the children, said, “Strike me pink.
I always did say that horse had a lot of sense, though.”
“Creatures, I give you yourselves,” said the strong, happy voice of Aslan. “I give to you forever this land of Narnia.
I give you the woods, the fruits, the rivers.
I give you the stars and I give you myself.
The Dumb( 哑的 ) Beasts whom I have not chosen are yours also.
Treat them gently and cherish( 爱护 ) them but do not go back to their ways lest( 以免 ) you cease( 停止 ) to be Talking Beasts.
For out of them you were taken and into them you can return. Do not so.”
“No, Aslan, we won’t, we won’t,” said everyone.
But one perky( 活泼的 ) jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) added in a loud voice, “No fear!” and everyone else had finished just before he said it so that his words came out quite clear in a dead silence;
and perhaps you have found out how awful that can be—say, at a party.
The Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) became so embarrassed( 尴尬的 ) that it hid its head under its wings as if it were going to sleep.
And all the other animals began making various queer( 奇怪的 ) noises which are their ways of laughing and which, of course, no one has ever heard in our world.
They tried at first to repress( 克制 ) it, but Aslan said:
“Laugh and fear not, creatures.
Now that you are no longer dumb( 哑的 ) and witless( 愚蠢的 ), you need not always be grave( 严肃的 ).
For jokes as well as justice come in with speech.”
So they all let themselves go.
And there was such merriment that the Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) himself plucked( 鼓起 ) up courage again and perched( 栖息 ) on the cab( 出租马车 )-horse’s head, between its ears, clapping its wings, and said:
“Aslan! Aslan! Have I made the first joke? Will everybody always be told how I made the first joke?”
“No, little friend,” said the Lion. “You have not made the first joke; you have only been the first joke.”
Then everyone laughed more than ever; but the Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) didn’t mind and laughed just as loud till the horse shook its head and the Jackdaw( 寒鸦 ) lost its balance and fell off,
but remembered its wings (they were still new to it) before it reached the ground.

article_info.previous: 面对魔力如此强大的狮子，女巫只有落荒而逃。此时Digory一行人发现了一件很有意思的事，掉进土里的铁棒长成了一根灯柱。当他们再次见到狮子，狮子的歌声也发生了一些变化。

article_info.share_words: And now you could hardly hear the song of the Lion; there was so much cawing, cooing, crowing, braying, neighing, baying, barking, lowing, bleating, and trumpeting.

question.cn: 狮子在“虚无”唱了歌之后，这个地方发生了什么？
question.en: What happened to “Nothing” since the Lion sang?

options.cn: 这个地方变得生机勃勃。

analysis: 文中提到：“For that is really the best description of what was happening. In all directions it was swelling into humps… there was so much cawing, cooing, crowing, braying, neighing, baying, barking, lowing, bleating, and trumpeting.”由此可知，这个地方万物复苏，生机勃勃，因此选B。

question.en: Why was Digory attracted to the Lion?

options.en: Because the Lion was big and bright.
Because the Lion was very cruel.
Because the Lion was so old.

analysis: 文中提到：“It was so big and so bright that he could not take his eyes off.”由此可知Digory是被狮子的高大和明亮深深地吸引了，因此选A。

question.en: How did the Lion choose the animals?

analysis: 文中提到：“And every now and then he would go up to two of them and touch their noses with his.”由此可知，狮子Aslan是通过触碰鼻子来选择动物的，因此选B。

question.cn: 这只叫“草莓”的马是狮子选中的动物之一吗？
question.en: Was the horse Strawberry one of the Talking Beasts chosen by the Lion?

analysis: 文中提到：“ ‘Good old Strawberry,’ said Polly. ‘I am glad he was one of the ones picked out to be a Talking Beast.’ ”由此可知那匹马“草莓”也是被狮子选中，成为了可以说话的动物，因此选A。

question.cn: 哪种动物成为了纳尼亚的第一个笑话？
question.en: Which animal became the first joke in Narnia?

analysis: 文中提到：“ ‘You have not made the first joke; you have only been the first joke.’ Then everyone laughed more than ever, but the Jackdaw didn’t mind and laughed. . . ”由此可知寒鸦成为了第一个笑话，因此选C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第33天
